word.entry: on the edge of a city
word.entryDescription: the part of a city that is furthest from its centre
word.entryExample: My village is on the edge of a city.

word.entryDescription: situated on the side of the body in which the heart is mostly located
word.entryExample: The lift is on the left next to the stairs.

word.entryDescription: used with a statement which is different when compared to the previous one
word.entryExample: On the other hand, some people think that using the death penalty sends the message that killing is acceptable.

word.entryDescription: on the way to somewhere
word.entryExample: The country is on the path to economic recovery.

word.entryDescription: situated on the side of the body which is away from the side on which the heart is mostly located
word.entryExample: The first door on the right leads to the toilet.

word.entryDescription: used to say that something is generally true
word.entryExample: On the whole, it was clear that most people enjoyed the event.

word.entryDescription: placed on the highest part of something
word.entryExample: Look at the flag on top of Buckingham Palace.

word.entryDescription: the number 1
word.entryExample: I'm in class one.

word.entryDescription: each other
word.entryExample: I hope Luigi gives you this letter, because I would like us to get to know one another.

word.entryDescription: a round vegetable with many ayers which has a strong smell and taste
word.entryExample: Onions sometimes make you cry.

word.entryDescription: describes glass, plastic, etc which you cannot see through
word.entryExample: We'll have an opaque window here because this is going to be the bathroom.

word.entryDescription: when you open something, it is no longer closed and you can move through it, or see inside it
word.entryExample: Can you open the door?

word.entryDescription: able and willing to accept new or different ideas or types of behaviour
word.entryExample: Be open-minded and hard-working. Those two qualities will get you far.

word.entryDescription: a musical play in which all or most of the words are sung
word.entryExample: She' s a famous opera singer.

word.entryDescription: computer software which controls the hardware and manages the programs
word.entryExample: I prefer the Apple operating system but Android has really developed in the last few years so don’t rule that out.

word.entryDescription: the act of dealing with a health problem by cutting into the body and repairing, removing or replacing something
word.entryExample: My father went into hospital for an operation.

word.entryDescription: what you think or believe about something
word.entryExample: I trust your opinion.

word.entryDescription: on the other side of; facing
word.entryExample: There's a shop opposite this hotel.

word.entryDescription: somebody who checks people's eyes and sells glasses
word.entryExample: I'm going to an optician to get some new glasses.

word.entryDescription: somebody who is positive about the future
word.entryExample: You're a true optimist!

word.entryDescription: a round fruit with a thick orange skin and juicy orange flesh
word.entryExample: Oranges grow on trees in hot countries.

word.entryDescription: a large group of musicians playing many different instruments and led by a conductor
word.entryExample: I play the violin in the school orchestra.

word.entryDescription: the way in which things or people are arranged or placed in relation to each other
word.entryExample: Just put their names in the alphabetical order.

word.entryDescription: to ask for food, drink or other goods to be served or delivered
word.entryExample: It's a lot easier for me to just order my groceries from the supermarket online and have them delivered to my home.

word.entryDescription: rock, soil, sand, etc from which metal can be obtained
word.entryExample: Silver ore was extracted by an army of slaves.

word.entryDescription: producing food without using artificial chemicals
word.entryExample: More people are buying more health food and organic food now than in the past.

word.entryDescription: able to plan your work, life, etc. well and in an efficient way
word.entryExample: A waiter has to be very organised and have good people skills.

word.entryDescription: a living thing
word.entryExample: The coral reef is a living organism.

word.entryDescription: the point at which something starts to exist
word.entryExample: We don't know the origin of this custom.

word.entryDescription: the price of something before the reduction
word.entryExample: 'Everything half price!' means that if you buy something, you will only pay 50% of the original price.

word.entryDescription: (especially of beliefs or behaviour) generally accepted or approved of; traditional
word.entryExample: In the West, the gap between orthodox and alternative medicine is narrowing.

word.entryDescription: the gradual passing of a liquid through a membrane
word.entryExample: Osmosis is a vital process in biological systems.

word.entryDescription: used to say that someone should do something because it is the best thing to do
word.entryExample: Steven really ought to quit drinking energy drinks.

word.entryDescription: used to refer to both me and at least one other person affected by an action when we also perform the action
word.entryExample: We always look after ourselves in the sun and wear hats and sun cream.

word.entryDescription: not growing at the current time
word.entryExample: If some vegetables are out of season, or don’t grow here, they're just shipped in from somewhere else.

word.entryDescription: unavailable in a particular shop
word.entryExample: I'm sorry, these shoes are completely out of stock.

word.entryDescription: suddenly and unexpectedly
word.entryExample: This promotion came completely out of the blue.

word.entryDescription: very shocking and unacceptable
word.entryExample: His behaviour was really outrageous

word.entryDescription: not inside
word.entryExample: The children are playing outside in the garden.

word.entryDescription: the areas on the edge of a town or city
word.entryExample: Hundreds of homes are springing up on the outskirts of Ashford, one of Britain's fastest growing towns.

word.entryDescription: to be greater or more important than something
word.entryExample: I think all the positives outweigh this so it’s not such a big deal if you really enjoy what you do.

word.entryDescription: to get an advantage over someone or something by acting more cleverly and often by using a trick
word.entryExample: I don't like playing chess with him. I have never managed to outwit him and win.

word.entryDescription: a piece of equipment or part of a cooker; it is like a box with door which you cook food in
word.entryExample: Put the cake in the oven for 30 minutes.

word.entryDescription: above or covering something
word.entryExample: Look! The cat is jumping over the table.
When you come out of the station, turn left and go over the bridge.

word.entryDescription: in a place nearby indicated by the speaker
word.entryExample: Can you stand next to your friend over there?

word.entryDescription: having to much experience or training for some job
word.entryExample: Darren did not want to go to the interview because he felt over-qualified.

word.entryDescription: generally, on the whole
word.entryExample: Overall, the project was successful.

word.entryDescription: cooked for too long
word.entryExample: Potatoes were overcooked.

word.entryDescription: filled with too many people
word.entryExample: The refugee camps are overcrowded and unable to give the people the help they need.
